Develop a technology. After you pay the?science?cost, score 2?science.
Score 2?science?and 2?culture.
Build one stage of a wonder; pay 3?resource?less
Increase your population. After you pay the?food?cost, gain 2?food.
For this turn, you have an extra 2?resource?for building and upgrading military units and 1 extra?military action.
Gain either 2?food?or 2?resource
Build or upgrade a mine or farm; pay 2?resource?less.
Build or upgrade an urban building; pay 2?resource?less.
Develop a technology. After you pay the?science?cost, score 3?science.
Upgrade a farm, mine or urban building; pay 3?resource?less.
Build one stage of a wonder; pay 4?resource?less
Increase your population. After you pay the?food?cost, gain 3?food.
For this turn, you have an extra 3?resource?for building and upgrading military units and 1 extra?military action.
Gain either 3?food?or 3?resource
Scores 4?science.
Build or upgrade a mine or farm; pay 3?resource?less.
Build or upgrade an urban building. Pay 3?resource?less.

For each civilization stronger than yours, you have extra?resource?for building and upgrading military?
2 in a 4-player game
3 in a 3-player game
6 in a 2-player game

For each civilization stronger than yours, you have extra?resource?for building and upgrading military?
2 in a 4-player game
3 in a 3-player game
6 in a 2-player game

For each civilization stronger than yours, you have extra?resource?for building and upgrading military?
2 in a 4-player game
3 in a 3-player game
6 in a 2-player game
Upgrade a farm, mine or urban building; pay 4?resource?less.

You score culture for each civilization with more culture than your have:
2 in a 4-player game
3 in a 3-player game
6 in a 2-player game

You score culture for each civilization with more culture than your have:
2 in a 4-player game
3 in a 3-player game
6 in a 2-player game

You score culture for each civilization with more culture than your have:
2 in a 4-player game
3 in a 3-player game
6 in a 2-player game
Build one stage of a wonder; pay 5?resource?less.

For each civilization stronger than yours, you have extra resource for building and upgrading military units this round:
3 in a 4-player game
5 in a 3-player game
8 in a 2-player game

For each civilization stronger than yours, you have extra resource for building and upgrading military units this round:
3 in a 4-player game
5 in a 3-player game
8 in a 2-player game

For each civilization stronger than yours, you have extra resource for building and upgrading military units this round:
3 in a 4-player game
5 in a 3-player game
8 in a 2-player game
For this turn, you have an extra 4?resource?for building and upgrading military units and 1 extra?military action.
Gain either 4 food or 4 resource.
Scores 6 science.
Build or upgrade an urban building; pay 4 resource less.
Your rival loses 1 population. You gain 2 food and 2 resource.
Your rival loses a total of up to 3 resource and/or food (your choice). You gain that many resource and food.
Destroy one of your rival's age A or age I urban building. You gain resource equal to half its cost, rounded up.
Take one colony from a rival. You gain (and he loses) its permanent bonuses but ignore any one-time gains.
Remove your rival's leader or incomplete wonder from play. You score 3 culture per level of the discarded card.
Your rival loses a total of up to 5 resource and/or food (your choice). You gain that many resource and food.
Destroy up to 2 of your rival's urban buildings: one of age II or older and one of age I or older. You gain resource equal to half their total cost, rounded up.
A rival loses up to 5 science. You score that many science.
Take up to 7 culture from your rival
your rival loses a total of up to 7 resource and/or food (your choice). You gain that many resource and food.
Destroy up to 2 of your rival's urban buildings: one of age III or older and one of age II or older. You gain resource equal to half their total cost, rounded up.
Each civilization gains 2 food.
Immediately, each civilization may either: increase its population; or build a farm, mine or urban building; or develop a technology. It costs 1 food or 1 resource or 1 science less than usual.
Each civilization gains 2 resource.
Each civilization gains 2 resource or 2 food (player's choice).
Each player draws 3 military cards
Each player with an unused worker may immediately build an Age A temple for free.
Each civilization scores 2 science.
Each civilization gains 1 population.
Each civilization scores 1 science and gains 1 resource and 1 food.
Each player with an unused worker may immediately build a Warrior unit for free.
If the civilization with the most culture points is one of the two weakest civilizations it loses 1 population.
The weakest civilization must destroy one of its own urban building, farm, or mine. The strongest civilization gains 3 resource.
The strongest civilization scores 4 culture. The weakest civilization loses 4 culture.
Each civilization immediately scores culture equal to the amount of culture it produces.
Each of the two strongest civilizations gains a total of 3 resource and/or food.
Each civilization produces food immediately. Ignore corruption and consumption.
All civilizations with the most happy face gain 1 population.
Each civilization produces resource immediately. Ignore corruption.
Each civilization loses 1 population.
Each of the two weakest civilizations lose a total of 2 resource and/or food.
Each civilization loses all stored food.
Each civlization immediately spends 2 civil action (without effect) per discontent worker.
The weakest civilization loses 1 population.
Each civilization immediately scores science equal to the amount of science it produces.
The strongest civilization takes 1 yellow token from the weakest civilization's yellow bank.

Each civilization loses 4 culture per discontent worker. All civilizations with the most discontent workers also returns 1 blue token to the box. If no one has discontent workers, this event has no effect.
The two strongest civilizations score 6 science.
The two weakest civilizations lose 3 culture and return 1 blue token to the box.

Each player produces immediately: 
Evaluate corruption.
Produce food.
Evaluate consumption.
Produce resource.
Each civilization loses half of its discontent workers, rounded up (return them to your yellow bank).
Each civilization with a leader that is not from the current age must remove that leader from play.
The weakest civilization loses 1 colony (the player choses which one).
The strongest civilization may immediately take up to 5 civil action in cards by giving up its next chance to take a political action. Replenish the card row. This may end the Age.
The civilization with the most culture points scores 5 culture.
The strongest civilization draws 5 military cards. The weakest civilization discards 3 military cards. In the game-ending age, culture is scored or lost instead.
Each civilization scores culture equal to the amount of science it produces.
Each civilization gains 1 food for each of its happy face (max 8).
Each player chooses one of his or her completed wonder from Age A or I and turns it face down. These wonders lose their effects and produce 2 culture instead.
The strongest scores 3 culture and gains 1 population. The weakest civilization loses 3 culture and 1 population.
The civilization with the least culture points destroys 1 urban building of each other civilization.
Each civilization scores culture equal to the amount of food it produces with a bonus of 4 culture if this exceeds consumption.
Each civilization scores 1 culture per level of each of its urban buildings.
Each civilization scores culture equal to double the amount of whatever it produces the least (science, culture, food, or resource). Ignore corruption and consumption.
Each civilization scores 3 culture per colony.
Each civilization scores 1 culture per level of each of its military units and arena.
Each civilization scores 2 culture per civil action and 1 culture per military action.
Each civilization scores 2 culture per happy face (no more than 16 points) and loses 2 culture per discontent worker.
Each civilization scores culture equal to the amount of resource its mines produce. (Ignore any production from other sources)
Each civilization scores 2 culture per content worker above 10.
Each civilization scores 2 culture per level of each of its government and special (blue) technologies.

Each civilizations score culture according to the relative amount of science it produces:
15/10/5/0 for 4-player
14/7/0 for 3-player
10/0 for 2-player

Each civilizations score culture according to the relative amount of science it produces:
15/10/5/0 for 4-player
14/7/0 for 3-player
10/0 for 2-player

Each civilizations score culture according to the relative amount of science it produces:
15/10/5/0 for 4-player
14/7/0 for 3-player
10/0 for 2-player

Each civilizations score culture according to their relative strength:
15/10/5/0 for 4-player
14/7/0 for 3-player
10/0 for 2-player

Each civilizations score culture according to their relative strength:
15/10/5/0 for 4-player
14/7/0 for 3-player
10/0 for 2-player

Each civilizations score culture according to their relative strength:
15/10/5/0 for 4-player
14/7/0 for 3-player
10/0 for 2-player
Each civilization scores 4 culture for each of its level III technologies (level II in Advanced game).
Each civilization scores 2 culture for each type of unit, urban building and special (blue) technology.

Each civilization scores culture for each wonders:
5 for age A
4 for age I
3 for age II
2 for age III
You have +1 strength for each of your military units. As a political action, you may remove Alexander from play and add 1 yellow token from the box to your yellow bank.
Every time you take a technology card from the card row, you score 1 science point.
On your turn, you may use one of your military action as a civil action. Taking a leader from the card row costs you 1 civil action less.

Each turn, you have an extra 1 resource for building and upgrading military units. When you replace Homer, you may give up the returned civil action to add 1 happy face to one of your completed wonders.
After you played a political action, you may play another political action. This ability can be used only once per game.
Increasing your population costs you 1 food less.
As a political action, you may remove Columbus from play to colonize a territory in your hand without sacrificing any unit.
For 1 military action, you can increase your population and build a new military unit with it. This costs you 1 food and 1 resource less than usual.
One or more of your infantry units can be considered cavalry for purposes of tactics. At the end of turn, score 3 culture if you are one of the 2 strongest civilizations (you win ties).
Your temple and government give you +1 strength for each of their happy face. At the beginning of your political phase, you may look at the top current event card.
Your best lab or library produces an additional amount of science equal to its level.\nEvery time you develop a technology, gain 1 resource.
Your temple, theater, and wonders produce an extra 1 culture for each of their happy face.\nWhen taking a wonder from the card row, you do not pay extra actions for the wonders you have.
You best lab or library produces an additional amount of science equal to its level.\nEvery time you develop a technology, you get back 1 spent civil action.
When colonizing, you may discard up to 2 military card to get +1 ship. One of your colonies produces 2 culture. Every colony after that produces 1 culture.

Each of your theater produces an extra 1 culture. It costs you 2 less science to develop theater technologies. Once during your turn, you may spend a civil action to upgrade any urban building to a theater of the same level or higher for the usual cost.

Each of your theater produces an extra 1 culture. It costs you 2 less science to develop theater technologies. Once during your turn, you may spend a civil action to upgrade any urban building to a theater of the same level or higher for the usual cost.
You have +2 strength for each different type of military unit you have. (The four types are infantry, cavalry, artillery, and air force)
A revolution costs you all of your military action instead of all of your civil action. You score 3 culture when declaring a revolution.
You best lab or library produces an additional amount of science equal to its level. Every time you develop a technology, you score 3 culture.
Each of your lab also produces resource equal to its level. When Bill Gates leaves play or at the end of the game, score culture equal to this additional production.
Your best theater produces twice as much culture.
You may not play aggression or war cards. Your rivals must pay twice as many military action to declare aggression or war against you.
Each of your lab produces an amount of culture equal to its level. However, each produces 1 science less.
On your turn, choose one: \nScore 3 culture; \nor you have 3 science and 3 resource for developing military unit technologies and building and upgrading military units.
The victor takes science equal to the strength advantage from the defeated civilization. Special (blue) technologies can be stolen instead equal to their cost.
The victor takes 1 yellow token plus 1 yellow token for every 5 point of strength advantage from the defeated civilization's yellow bank.
The victor takes 5 culture + 1 culture for each point of strength advantage from the defeated civilization.
